The amounts in this amendment are the estimated need to establish a public defender office
covering each locality in the state, which would include 26 new offices, and as many as 400
additional assistant attorneys and 750 additional support positions. These estimates are assumed
to cover any costs associated with the bill's direction for the Commission to re-establish a
dedicated Appellate Defender's Office. This is a placeholder amendment until final costs are
known. Companion amendments to the Criminal Fund, Compensation Board, and Worker's
Compensation Commission provide for additional costs anticipated to result from the bill.

descriptionFull:

agencyName: Education: Higher Education FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment requests funding to increase the number of nursing graduates by 30 each year
through the JMU "Fast Flex" Nursing Program. The
descriptionFull:
This amendment requests funding to increase the number of nursing graduates by 30 each year
through the JMU "Fast Flex" Nursing Program. The program will allow students to complete
their core nursing course work in one calendar year, as opposed to two academic years, getting
nurses in the field quicker. Classes, which will be delivered in a hybrid of on-campus and online
formats, as well as clinical placements will take place on nights and weekends. The program
will be open to anyone who has earned 36 credit hours, completed certain prerequisite courses,
and met other criteria. Resources requested to launch this program will cover expenses related
to program faculty, support staff, supplies, technology needs, and student scholarships.

agencyName: Education: Other Education FY24-25 FY25-26
Education: Other Education FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $2.3 million the second year from the general fund to increase the
state aid to local public libraries. This funding
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.3 million the second year from the general fund to increase the
state aid to local public libraries. This funding represents the fourth and final installment of a
four-year plan to fully fund the state library aid formula by fiscal year 2026. This plan is
established as the objective of the General Assembly in Subsection D of Item 227 that was
enacted in 2022. This amendment also amends language to state that is the objective of the
General Assembly to maintain full funding of the state aid to local libraries formula and
requires the Library of Virginia to report by November 15 each year its estimate of the amount
of funding required to maintain full funding in the next fiscal year.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.6 million the second year from the general fund to support the
renovation of the Bassett Branch Library which ser
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.6 million the second year from the general fund to support the
renovation of the Bassett Branch Library which serves part of Henry and Patrick County. The
plan includes renovation and expansion to the existing building, parking, landscaping, and
outfitting of the inside of the facility. Once complete, the library will provide increase facility
capacity, an enlarged Children and Youth Department, public meeting spaces, a centralized
computer area, and improved ADA accessibility.

agencyName: Education: Other Education FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:

the Science Museum of Virginia to hire three full ti
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 and 6.00 FTEs each year from the general fund to allow
the Science Museum of Virginia to hire three full time security positions and three full time
educator positions. In the last decade, the Museum's annual visitation has doubled to over half a
million individuals without any substantial increase in staffing. This dramatic increase in
visitors has created the need to increase staff to maintain safety and meet classroom needs.

reimbursement of up to 25 percent of renovation costs. This cost share is in accordance with ยงยง
53.1-80 through 53.0-82.2, Code of Virginia, which directs state reimbursement of a quarter of
costs incurred by localities for construction or renovation of jail facilities. Specifically, this
project involves the renovation of property at 2690 Elmhurst Lane, formerly the Hampton
Roads Regional Jail, for future use as the Portsmouth City Jail.

agencyName: Request to Amend House Bill 1600, as Introduced
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.0 million from the general fund the second year to increase
funding for the Earn to Learn Nursing Education Accel
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.0 million from the general fund the second year to increase
funding for the Earn to Learn Nursing Education Acceleration program. The Earn to Learn
program offers competitive grants to both public and nonprofit private colleges and universities
that partner with health systems to offer nursing students the opportunity to earn a competitive
wage while also earning credit for clinical hours toward degree requirements. The goal of the
program is to address the health care workforce shortage by expanding the number of trained
nurses in Virginia.

Birmingham Green Workforce Development Training C
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $75,000 from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 to establish the
Birmingham Green Workforce Development Training Center. Birmingham Green offers the
only CNA training program in Northern Virginia and is a crucial resource for individuals from
underserved communities. The Workforce Development Training Center will be an expansion
of their current workforce development efforts to train CNAs, with new career training
opportunities for its workforce and for staff from other health care operations.

descriptionFull:

governments to update or establish prescription drug box programs. These updates ensure
compliance with new standards for secure drug disposal to prevent misuse and environmental
harm, in accordance with the latest federal and state regulatory changes to prescription drug box
programs.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides funding for the University of Virginia Health System Ambulance
Department for the purchase of an additional ambulanc
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides funding for the University of Virginia Health System Ambulance
Department for the purchase of an additional ambulance to serve patients in Northern Virginia.
This purchase will ensure Medicare, Medicaid, uninsured and underinsured patients in
Northern/Central Virginia will have access to emergent and non-emergent transportation for
purposes of receiving inpatient and outpatient services across UVA Community Health's patient
care locations in Prince William and Haymarket. It will allow for timelier discharges and
additional bed space for patients in need of inpatient services. In-house transportation also
reduces the cost burden on the patient.

descriptionFull:

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $750,000 from the general fund the first year to restore funding for
community organizations for HIV/AIDS prevention and
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $750,000 from the general fund the first year to restore funding for
community organizations for HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment services. During the 2024-26
biennium, the AIDS services grant was eliminated and the community HIV testing and Status
Neutral Services grants were combined. This amendment will restore funding for community
HIV testing services to the 2023 levels.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26

Department of Health, working with Virginia univer
descriptionFull:
This amendment provide $5.0 million from the general fund the second year to the Virginia
Department of Health, working with Virginia universities and private businesses, to create a
pilot program for mobile clinics within two maternal health deserts in Virginia, as well as
funding for data collection to measure the effectiveness of the program. The goal of the program
is to improve access in underserved communities and reduce transportation and geographic
barriers.

descriptionFull:

pending legislation to be introduced in the 2025 Session which directs the Virginia Department
of Health to create a membership-based mobile application available to prenatal, pregnant, and
postpartum individuals who are eligible for Medicaid. Funding is based on a tiered pricing
proposal based on monthly active users and a projection of annual users based on the Virginia
Medicaid population.

awareness campaign, develop and distribute educational materials, and create an online resource
hub focused on perinatal and postpartum depression. The bill requires the Department to submit
an annual report to the Governor and the General Assembly on the implementation of the bill,
with the first annual report due by December 31, 2026.

descriptionFull:

insurance contract, policy, or plan that includes coverage for prescription drugs on an outpatient
basis, for contraceptive drugs and contraceptive devices, as defined in the bill, including those
available over-the-counter. The bill prohibits a health insurance carrier from imposing upon any
person receiving contraceptive benefits pursuant to the provisions of the bill any copayment,
coinsurance payment, or fee, except in certain circumstances. A portion of the funding shall be
used for a public awareness campaigns on no cost contraceptive coverage and a portion shall be

or low income communities, and those organizations with less than $5.0 million in annual

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides a total of $1.3 million in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for
operational support for four initiatives aimed
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides a total of $1.3 million in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for
operational support for four initiatives aimed at strengthening Virginia's health workforce
infrastructure. Funding will support the establishment of a Nurse Workforce Center, the creation
of a Direct Support Professional training program, the development of a Health Workforce
Database Center, and access to the All Payers Claims Database.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $136,000 in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for the VHWDA
to study anesthesiology residency capacity and enro
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $136,000 in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for the VHWDA
to study anesthesiology residency capacity and enrollment in Virginia's CRNA programs, in
collaboration with State Council of Higher Education for Virginia and other relevant
stakeholders, Funding will be used for an external consultant to lead the study, staff time to
provide coordination and administrative support, equipment and supplies for data analysis and
communication of findings, travel, and miscellaneous support. This is a recommendation of the
Joint Commission on Health Care.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $4.0 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 to support
operating costs of free clinics that are members of th
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $4.0 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 to support
operating costs of free clinics that are members of the Virginia Association of Free and
Charitable Clinics. Funding will be used to provide medical, dental, vision, speech, hearing and
behavioral health care, as well as prescription medications and substance use disorder services
to uninsured and underinsured patients.

agencyName: Request to Amend House Bill 1600, as Introduced
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $150,000 in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for the Virginia
Telehealth Network to conduct a feasibility study an
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $150,000 in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for the Virginia
Telehealth Network to conduct a feasibility study and develop a plan to implement a pilot
program for Pharmacy Care Hubs in Virginia. Pharmacy Care Hubs serve as telehealth access
points in pharmacies, where reliable internet service is available to provide access to telehealth
services and pharmacy staff are available during telehealth visits to help patients use the
technology. Pharmacy staff may also perform various tests as directed by a physician,
administer vaccines, or provide therapeutic injections during the telehealth visit. If medication is
prescribed during the visit, the pharmacist may dispense the medication prior to the end of the
appointment. This is a recommendation of the Joint Commission on Health Care.
primaryRecipientName: the Virginia Telehealth Network to conduct a feasibility study and develop a plan to implement a pilot program for Pharmacy Care Hubs in Virginia
recipientRawText: for the Virginia Telehealth Network to conduct a feasibility study and develop a plan to implement a pilot program for Pharmacy Care Hubs in Virginia

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides a total of $1.6 million in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for
the VHWDA to establish the Virginia Oral Healt
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides a total of $1.6 million in fiscal year 2026 from the general fund for
the VHWDA to establish the Virginia Oral Health Loan Repayment Program for dentists and
dental hygienists that practice in underserved areas of the Commonwealth. Currently, the
Virginia Department of Health has statutory authority for a dentist loan repayment program for
graduates of accredited dental schools who meet the criteria determined by the Board of Health,
with the requirement that the recipient agree to perform a period of dental service in this
Commonwealth in an underserved area or a dental health professional shortage area, however,
the loan repayment program has been unfunded for a number of years.

descriptionFull:

operating costs of Federally Qualified Health Centers that are members of the Virginia
Community Healthcare Association. Funding will be used to provide medical, dental, vision,
speech, hearing and behavioral health care, as well as prescription medications and substance
use disorder services to uninsured and underinsured patients.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4.5 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 to Families
Forward Virginia to provide the research needed t
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.5 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 to Families
Forward Virginia to provide the research needed to determine whether the CHIP of Virginia
home visiting program meets federal standards as an evidence based program and can become
eligible for federal funding through the Maternal, Infant, Early Childhood Home Visiting
Program. Families Forward Virginia is a non-profit organization that provides statewide home
visiting programs to eligible Virginia families. CHIP of Virginia, one of three home visiting
programs implemented by Families Forward Virginia, promotes healthy pregnancy and positive
child development by pairing families with integrated teams of registered nurses and parent
educations. CHIP of Virginia has documented positive outcomes, but additional research is
necessary to collect sufficient evidence on the program to meet federal criteria. Obtaining
certification is a necessary step in determining whether CHIP of Virginia could be eligible for
federal MIECHV program funds. If federal funds were available, the program could expand
access to home visiting programs for additional vulnerable and underserved families in
Virginia. This is a recommendation of the Joint Commission on Health Care.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $500,000 from the general fund the second year to Birth in Color to
fund the establishment of a billing hub for doul
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 from the general fund the second year to Birth in Color to
fund the establishment of a billing hub for doula services. The billing hub will handle billing for
doulas serving underserved populations free of charge, including billing private insurance and
Medicaid on behalf of participating doulas. The hub will defray the administrative burden for
doulas serving underserved communities, helping support and expand the doula workforce. The
initial investment of $500,000 will pay for the hiring of necessary full time and contract staff,
relevant software and hardware purchases and fees and relevant administrative expenses,
including but not limited to billing software.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $600,000 from the general fund the second year to Tri-Area
Community Health to purchase a motor coach bus to develop into a mammography outreach
program. The University of Virginia will outfit the inside with technology and equipment,
which will provide for 3D mammograms through mobile outreach. The bus will be able to
provide diagnostic mammography, ultrasound, and biopsies. The mobile unit will serve
approximately 2,500 square miles including the rural areas of Carroll, Floyd, Franklin, Grayson,
and Patrick Counties.

descriptionFull:

Family Clinic at the Up Center in Virginia Beach to sustain and expand services to veterans,
active-duty service members and their families. Funding will be matched 50/50 by the clinic.
Funding will help expand services to serve more of the eligible population and will cover
clinician and staff salaries, operating and facility costs, IT, and patient transportation.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $2.0 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 for the

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.0 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 for the
potential fiscal impact of House Bill 2300, which would establish the Residential Well Water
Testing and Treatment Program to allow the Department of Health's Office of Drinking Water
to test and treat contaminated drinking water through grants for the use of eligible treatment or
filtration systems in private residential wells. The bill also directs the State Board of Health to
adopt regulations to utilize point-of-use or point-of-entry drinking water treatment or filtration
systems to remove or significantly reduce concentrations of contaminants of concern that meet
or exceed any maximum contaminant level or health advisory for the same contaminant adopted
by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

descriptionFull:

descriptionFull:
This amendment adds language to require the Department of Medical Assistance Services to

and postpartum Medicaid managed care members. Medicaid managed care orgnizations may
choose to participate by providing these services to prevent these individuals from needing
more resource intensive services. Language spells out the types of food services to be provided
through this optional benefit.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:

nongeneral funds the second year to increase personal c
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $149.1 million from the general fund and $168.1 million from
nongeneral funds the second year to increase personal care, respite, and companion services
rates by 15 percent for consumer-directed and agency-directed care. Language provides the
agency with emergency regulatory authority to implement these changes in fiscal year 2026.
Chapter 2, 2024 Special Session 1, provided two rate increases for personal care services. The
first was a 2 percent increase in personal care rates, effective January 1, 2024 and the second
was a 2 percent increase in personal care rates, effective July 1, 2024.

amendments to the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid for the two Developmental
Disability Waivers to provide Medicaid payment for designated staff support for adults with
developmental disability in acute care settings. Language sets forth requirements for these
payments and provides the agency with emergency regulation authority to implement the
changes.

The introduced budget provides funding and language to unbundle these payments only when
administered for a serious mental illness. This language extends this provision for cases of
substance use disorder.

fund the second year to provide Medicaid coverage for neurobehavioral and neurorehabilitation
facilities to support individuals with traumatic brain injuries and neurocognitive disorders by
January 1, 2026. Language provides for the adoption of emergency regulations to effect such
change.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.7 million from the general fund and $9.5 million from nongeneral
funds the second year to provide Medicaid supple
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.7 million from the general fund and $9.5 million from nongeneral
funds the second year to provide Medicaid supplemental payments to Sheltering Arms
Rehabilitation Center. Sheltering Arms treats one out of every four Medicaid patients in
Virginia in need of inpatient rehabilitation services. The services provided treat the most acute
injuries to this population, including stroke, spinal cord injury, and traumatic brain injury. As a
result, SAI has the highest cost of services compared to other rehabilitation hospitals in
Virginia. Because DMAS calculates its rates using a pool containing all rehabilitation hospitals,
Sheltering Arms effective reimbursement is comparatively lower than other rehabilitation
hospitals. For fiscal year 2025, Sheltering Arms will be reimbursed at a level less than 69
percent of cost of providing inpatient services to Medicaid patients. Other inpatient
rehabilitation providers are reimbursed at a level closer to 80 percent of cost. This proposal was
included in the agency's fall 2024 budget submissions.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4.9 million from the general fund and $5.1 million from nongeneral
funds the second year to provide Medicaid covera
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.9 million from the general fund and $5.1 million from nongeneral
funds the second year to provide Medicaid coverage of genetic testing of critically ill infants
with rare diseases. More than 30 million Americans are living with one of more than 10,000
known rare diseases, and 1 in 2 patients diagnosed is a child. Rare diseases, defined as a disease
or condition that affects less than 200,000 people in the United States, 4 are very difficult to
188 Item Order
Request to Amend House Bill 1600, as Introduced
diagnose. Improving coverage of and access to comprehensive genetic testing tools like rapid
Whole Genome Sequencing and enhancing newborn screening programs can help people living
with rare diseases get diagnosed more quickly and effectively. Rapid diagnosis can reduce the
number of invasive test, procedures and hospital stays, and reduce the care burden on families
and caregivers. Currently 14 states provide Medicaid coverage for Rapid Whole Genome
Sequencing for infants, with Michigan's Medicaid coverage estimated at providing net savings
of $4,155 per patient.

descriptionFull:

fellowship slots funded through the program.

patients. Language which limits these medications is not based on any current standards of care.
Removal of this language, returns the authority to the Department of Medical Assistance
Services to determine appropriate utilization of anti-obesity medications, which is provided in
existing budget language in Item 288, paragraph QQQQ.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $11.3 million from the general fund and $11.8 million from
nongeneral funds the second year to increase Medicaid rat
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $11.3 million from the general fund and $11.8 million from
nongeneral funds the second year to increase Medicaid rates for ABA services by 10 percent.
Language also directs the agency to create a billing code for care coordination for behavioral
health services that are classified by a Current Procedural Terminology code, including ABA
services. The current reimbursement rates for ABA services are based on a rate study that was
conducted prior to 2018 and do not adequately cover the cost to deliver this service. This has
created significant workforce challenges that have constrained access to this important and
time-sensitive service. Adopting a 10 percent rate increase would provide the same treatment to
ABA services that was given to all the other Medicaid behavioral health services that received a
rate increase in January, 2024, and will help to better align the reimbursement rate for this
service with the increased costs to deliver it, particularly the cost to adequately pay and retain
staff

descriptionShort:

descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $43.3 million from the general fund and $45.1 million from nongeneral
funds the second year to increase Medicaid rates for nursing facility services due to the
additional cost to implement state mandated staffing standards. The second enactment clause of
Chapters 482 and 483 of the 2023 Acts of Assembly require that the Medicaid base rates reflect
the cost of the increased staffing in order for the Virginia mandate to be enforced. Based on the
most recent staffing data available from the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS

agencyName: Health and Human Resources
descriptionShort:
This amendment modifies language related to the nursing facility value-based payments. This
change would utilize the same performance cycle,
descriptionFull:
This amendment modifies language related to the nursing facility value-based payments. This
change would utilize the same performance cycle, but, after a transition year, would shift from
making the value-based payment with a 7 to 10-month lag to an on-going, real-time payment
associated with when facilities submit claims. This would be accomplished as a VBP per day
amount, based on the same performance results, but which would be included in the rate paid
through the normal claims process in each rate year that immediately follows each performance
year. While the program is well-received and effective, the lump sum approach does not address
the fact that many of the initiatives undertaken to address quality concerns, such as staff
augmentation, are ongoing daily costs. As lump sums received long after the fact, day-to-day
operations are stressed to maintain the initiatives without the additional reimbursement as the
costs are incurred. Additionally, lenders are not willing to provide credit based on potential
future โbonusesโ that are unknown in amounts, and budgeting is much more difficult given the
uncertainty of the retroactive lump sum VBP payment approach. For many providers using
accrual accounting principles, they also end up paying taxes on an โexpectedโ amount of VBP
revenue before they have even received the revenue, further stressing their finances to maintain
the initiatives while awaiting the potential payout each year. Additionally, the lump sum
approach has caused additional administrative costs for the five Medicaid managed care
organizations (MCOs

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $132.0 million from the general fund and $132.0 million from
nongeneral funds in fiscal year 2025 and $154.5 million from the general fund and $154.5
million from nongeneral funds in fiscal year 2026 to increase personal care, respite, and
companion services rates by 30 percent for agency-directed care. This will result in a $6.86 per
hour increase for Northern Virginia and a $5.83 per hour increase in the rest of the state. This
increase will provide better compensation and cover the cost of increasing Registered Nursing
oversight, insurance, worker's compensation, health insurance, electronic visit verification
software, rent and all other direct and indirect costs of care. Chapter 2, 2024 Special Session 1,
provided two recent rate increases for personal care services. The first was a two percent
increase in personal care rates, effective January 1, 2024 and the second was a two percent
increase in personal care rates, effective July 1, 2024.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4,960 from the general fund and $12,228 from nongeneral funds
the second year to expand the Medicaid benefit for po
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4,960 from the general fund and $12,228 from nongeneral funds
the second year to expand the Medicaid benefit for post-partum doula visits, increasing from
four to six visits and extending the timeline allowable to 12 months as required by pending
legislation to be considered in the 2025 Session. Doula service can be a cost-effective approach
to improving maternal and child health, with potential significant Medicaid savings through
improved outcomes.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $520,221 from the general fund and $2.2 million from nongeneral
funds the second year for the fiscal impact of House
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $520,221 from the general fund and $2.2 million from nongeneral
funds the second year for the fiscal impact of House Bill 2102, which directs the Department of
Medical Assistance Services to seek federal authority to implement presumptive eligibility for
pregnant individuals, in addition to the existing hospital presumptive eligibility program and, if
the department receives such authority, allows the department to authorize qualified entities to
make determinations of presumptive eligibility for pregnant individuals. This amendment
provides funding for the Department of Medical Assistance Services to seek federal authority
through any necessary State Plan amendments to implement presumptive eligibility for pregnant
women in accordance with 42 C.F.R. ยง 435.1103. Funding covers necessary systems updates,
hiring personnel as needed, and other costs. Expenses are expected to be higher in year one due
to start-up costs. The department shall determine the methods used by qualified entities to verify
income and shall implement quality control measures to reduce the risk of fraud or error. The
department already has quality control measures in place for Hospital Presumptive Eligibility
and may be able to use similar methods for this policy, which should offset costs. Additionally,
should a completed application not be submitted by the last day of the month in which screening
occurs, coverage will cease meaning that an individual cannot be covered for longer than 60
days without filing a completed application.

resistant epilepsy.

provision for payment of medical assistance for violence prevention services, defined in the bill,
provided by a qualified violence prevention professional to an individual who receives medical
treatment for an injury sustained as a result of community violence, defined in the bill, and who
is determined by a health care provider to be at risk of repeat injury or retaliation. The bill
directs the Department of Medical Assistance Services to convene a work group to advise the
Board on the design and implementation of the violence prevention services benefit and to post
on its website the date upon which violence prevention services may be provided and billed
pursuant to the provisions of the bill.

descriptionFull:

specifies that consultations provided through telemedicine services, including audio-only
telemedicine services where applicable, shall be included in such provision.

parent or spouse paid caregiver and unpaid adult caregivers. Parents and spouses of minor

the Code of Virginia that currently require one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours
worked for home health workers to cover all employees of private employers and state and local
governments. The bill requires that employees who are employed and compensated on a fee-for-
service basis accrue paid sick leave in accordance with regulations adopted by the
Commissioner of Labor and Industry. This funding covers the cost to implement these
provisions by the Department of Medical Assistance Services for the Medicaid program.

campaign will use a multi-tiered approach to educate young people and parents about mental

funding will be used to develop and procure advertising and marketing materials,
advertisements, and content creation.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $18.0 million the second year from the general fund to support six
Marcus Alert sites that have completed their planning and were supposed to implement in 2024
but did not receive funding to do so, as well as to fund six additional Marcus Alert sites. This
will allow Virginia to keep pace to have all Marcus Alert programs in place by 2028 as required
by Virginia Code. This amendment also brings all Marcus Alert programs to a funding level of
$972,000 per year, which comports with the original cost estimate provided by the Department
of Planning and Budget when the Marcus Alert mandate passed in 2020. Currently, Marcus
Alert sites are receiving $600,000 per year.

descriptionFull:

2024 Special Session I provided $775,000 in each year of the 2024-26 biennium for this
purpose. State contracted brain injury providers report high attrition and difficulty filling open
positions because of non-competitive salaries and benefits. Delivery of programs and services
suffer and client needs can go unmet.

Centers for Independent Living would receive an increase of $75,000.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.0 million from the general fund the second year for Virginiaโs
state safety net services for persons with brain injury, who continue to experience waiting lists
for services and struggles to meet existing demands from this challenging population that
requires specialized supports. This funding would support the existing state-contracted safety
net brain injury services system to provide for increased statewide coverage of critical services
and strengthen existing programs to include: hiring additional case managers, clinical
professional staff, equipment/IT modernization, statewide awareness/education efforts, and
other critical supports to meet the growing demands for brain injury services across the state.

descriptionFull:

interdisciplinary plan of care and dementia case management to two Area Agencies on Aging
located in Richmond and Roanoke to serve 200 individuals diagnosed with dementia. Language
provides for an annual report on the status of the programs and results. This is a
recommendation of the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Commission and the

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $500,000 the first year and $2,000,000 the second year from the
general fund to the County of Fairfax to support the
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 the first year and $2,000,000 the second year from the
general fund to the County of Fairfax to support the Washington Area Villages Exchange in the
creation of a pilot program to reduce the public health risk of social isolation among older
Virginians by expanding the availability of Villages statewide. Villages are a proven means of
combatting isolation while enabling older adults to age in place and live safely and
independently in their homes.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $350,000 the second year from the general fund to create a statewide
landscape assessment and strategic response pla
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $350,000 the second year from the general fund to create a statewide
landscape assessment and strategic response plan to human trafficking as well as to establish a
statewide referral mechanism to connect survivors to appropriate services and collect data on
trafficking trends. This amendment includes $100,000 for the assessment and strategic response
plan and $250,000 to contract with an external agency, such as Safe House Project, to
implement the referral mechanism to connect survivors to services, collect and analyze data, and
report to law enforcement through a technology-based platform that has multilingual capability
and robust privacy measures to protect the identity and personal identifying information of
survivors and individuals reporting trafficking cases. This amendment also includes an annual
report detailing progress on the assessment and response plan, outcomes from the referral
mechanism, and recommendations for future funding and program expansion.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $100,000 the first year and $410,000 the second year from the
general fund and 1.00 FTE the first year and 3.50 FTEs
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $100,000 the first year and $410,000 the second year from the
general fund and 1.00 FTE the first year and 3.50 FTEs the second year to establish a pilot
program to provide legal services to parents whose children are at risk of entering foster care in
order to reduce the number of children who enter foster care. Any non-profit legal organization
that has been approved by the Virginia State Bar as a qualified legal services provider may
apply for funding and enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Social
Services to provide legal services to parents who are subject of an investigation by Child
Protective Services and to parents contemplating entering into a Parental Child Safety
Placement Agreement. Funding is also included to support new positions at the Department of
Social Services to administer the funds and to receive and review quarterly and annual reports
from the qualified legal services providers.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $500,000 the second year from the general fund to establish a child
welfare workforce support program. The workforce
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 the second year from the general fund to establish a child
welfare workforce support program. The workforce program will include a confidential peer
support helpline to offer child welfare workers real time support from retired employees with
experience in the agency and knowledge of how to address the stressors of the job. The program
will also include a pilot program of the Community Resiliency Model, an evidence-based model
that focuses on providing workers with the skills to help themselves and others after
experiencing trauma and stress. Funding in this amendment would fund a program coordinator
in the Office of Trauma and Resilience Policy, a team of part-time retired workers to staff the
helpline, a team of facilitators trained in the Community Resiliency Model, research to measure
program outcomes, and related administrative costs.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26

descriptionFull: This amendment is self-explanatory.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26

descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $14.5 million the second year from the general fund to increase the
Auxiliary Grant Rate for assisted living facilities to $2,500 per month. The state provides 80
percent of funding for this program while the localities provide 20 percent.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:

Auxiliary Grant Rate for assisted living facilities
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $14.5 million the second year from the general fund to increase the
Auxiliary Grant Rate for assisted living facilities to $2,500 per month. The state provides 80
percent of funding for this program while the localities provide 20 percent.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources
descriptionShort:
This amendment proposes language to ensure that the auxiliary grant calculation is to be paid
as a full allocation of the amount approved by
descriptionFull:
This amendment proposes language to ensure that the auxiliary grant calculation is to be paid
as a full allocation of the amount approved by the General Assembly and ensuring the rate is
approved "in addition" to other income, rathe than "the difference of" as currently
implemented.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $2.8 million the second year from the general fund to fund the fiscal
impact of House Bill 1964, which creates the B
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.8 million the second year from the general fund to fund the fiscal
impact of House Bill 1964, which creates the Bright Futures program. Bright Futures will
provide a monthly maintenance care payment to individuals aged 21 to 24 to support their
housing costs as they transition to adulthood and self-sufficiency. The percentage of the
monthly stipend received will depend on the recipient's age and will gradually decrease each
year up until their 24th birthday. Age 21 would receive 75 percent of the current maintenance
care rate, age 22 would receive 50 percent of the current rate, and age 23 would receive 25
percent of the current rate. The current maintenance care rate is $836 per month. Funding from
this amendment will support the cost of the maintenance payments as well as support local
departments of social services to provide case management for the individuals participating in
Bright Futures.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $425,750 the second year from the general fund for the Department
of Social Services to expand the existing program
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $425,750 the second year from the general fund for the Department
of Social Services to expand the existing program with current providers to find relative and
fictive kin at the time of entry into foster care or when an out-of-home placement is needed
before entry into foster care. The current program eligibility is for youth who are placed in
congregate care or who have been in foster care for twelve months or more and are not placed
with kinship foster parents. Additional funding will enable existing providers to hire additional
staff for this program, expanding services to ensure that children entering fostering care are
promptly assigned a kinship specialist to locate relatives and fictive kin. Additional staff will
serve more children in more locations across the state.

Voice, the Richmond-based radio reading services fo
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $20,000 from the general fund the second year to expand Virginia
Voice, the Richmond-based radio reading services for individuals with vision impairments to
the Southwest Virginia region, enabling access to these critical services. Funding will be used to
purchase new equipment including hands free audio speakers to provide to listeners in the new
region. The amendment also includes language to require the Department of the Blind and
Vision Impaired to assess the usage of each radio reading service by evaluating the number of
listeners each service reaches, utilizing available technology to track and measure audience
engagement effectively and distribute funding to each service based on the number of listeners.

descriptionFull:

its organizational structure in the Code of Virginia and Appropriations Act, the disposition of
funding, the feasibility of the incorporation of Stormwater Local Assistance Fund, and other
topics as directed by the amendment. The recommendations of the workgroup are required to be
submitted to the Chairs of specified House and Senate committees and the State Water
Commission by November 1, 2026.

This amendment provides $1.4 million from the general fund and four positions in fiscal year

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.4 million from the general fund and four positions in fiscal year
2026 to support the opening of Falkland State Conservation Area in Halifax County. The 7,264
acre Falkland State Conservation Area was donated to the Department of Conservation and
Recreation in 2021. The property includes the historic Syndor House Louse, two natural area
preserve dedication areas, a guest house and numerous farm building. The funding request and
staffing will support the beginning of public access and the development and maintenance of
minimal recreation facilities to include interpretive hiking trails, an equestrian trail, parking
areas, habitat management and restoration areas, and the development of signage and
educational programming.

descriptionFull:

Certainty program. This represents a $31.2 million from the general fund more than the $17.4

represent the most recent available cash flow estimate for projects in the current biennium.
Chapter 2 included $400.0 million over the biennium for these projects.

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment proposes an additional $50 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2025
and $150 million from the general fund in fiscal
descriptionFull:
This amendment proposes an additional $50 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2025
and $150 million from the general fund in fiscal year 2026 be provided to support the Richmond
Combined Sewer Overflow Project. This is in addition to $50 million from the general fund in
fiscal year 2025 provided by Chapter 2, 2024 Special Session 1, and $50 million proposed by
the Governor in House Bill 1600 as introduced, for a total of $300 million to support the
Richmond Combined Sewer Overflow project over the biennium. The amendment further
stipulates these funds be deposited in the Combined Sewer Overflow Matching Fund
established pursuant to ยง 62.1-241.12, Code of Virginia. The City of Richmond has requested
that a total of $500 million be provided by the Commonwealth by the end of fiscal year 2028 to
support the execution of contracts necessary to complete all projects by the statutorily mandated
date of July 1, 2035.

descriptionFull:

necessary to protect the site from additional flooding.

descriptionFull:

retirement system and adds local E-911 dispatchers on the list of local employees eligible to
receive enhanced retirement benefits. The funding supports the administrative changes needed
to effectuate the change. The bill includes a delayed effective date making the benefit changes
effective July 1, 2026. Once effective, there would be an estimated $630,000 general fund cost
annually for providing the benefits beginning in the next beinnium.

the second year. The actual impact is to be determined.

therefore, no revenue adjustment is necessary.

descriptionFull:

Child Tax Credit pursuant to legislation authorized in the 2025 General Assembly as a
placeholder. The credit would be a refundable $300 credit per child aged 12 or younger in
households making up to $100,000 adjusted gross income. The actual revenue impact is to be
determined.

companion amendment in Item 3-5.05 that modifies language related to excess fees collected by
clerks of the circuit courts. The effect of companion language amendment is to return the local
share of excess fees to two-thirds of amounts collected, consistent with the Code of Virginia.
This preliminary estimate of the general fund revenue loss is intended to reflect an increase in
the local share of excess fees, offset by a decline in state reimbursement for fringe benefits,
pursuant to ยง 51.1-137, Code of Virginia, specific to those local offices that collect excess fees.

insurance procured during the preceding calendar year on behalf of a commuter rail system
jointly operated by the Northern Virginia Transportation Commission and the Potomac and
Rappahannock Transportation District.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4.0 million GF the second year to cover court-appointed counsel

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.0 million GF the second year to cover court-appointed counsel
payments at defendants' first appearance and related needs. This amendment and a companion
amendment in Item 40 compliment Senate Bill 1227, which implements counsel at first
appearance in non-public defender localities. The amount assumes $2.2 million for court-
appointed counsel payments, based on 2019 data collected by the Virginia State Crime
Commission, and $1.8 million for associated costs such as court improvements. Grants shall be
given to localities that have demonstrated efforts or intentions to implement counsel at first
appearance, and priority shall be given to courts in localities that are identified as โhighโ on the
Virginia Department of Housing and Community Development fiscal stress index.

guardian ad litem payment rate from $75/hour to $90/ho
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.0 million GF the second year to support an increase in the
guardian ad litem payment rate from $75/hour to $90/hour for time spent in court and $55/hour
to $65/hour for time spent out of court. According to the Office of the Executive Secretary,
current Criminal Fund balances are projected to cover the costs in FY 2026, but the ongoing
annual Criminal Fund appropriation would need to increase by approximately $4.0 million to
accommodate the rate change beginning in FY 2027. The goal of the rate change is to increase
the number of available guardian ad litem, who represent children, incapacitated persons, and
persons with a disability in certain cases.

Commonwealth agencies, including universities.

This amendment provides $100,000 from the general fund the second fiscal year in order to

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $100,000 from the general fund the second fiscal year in order to
implement the actions outlined in Senate Bill 840, which specifies certain criteria for a child to
be considered engaged in the work of content creation and prohibits a child who is under 14
years of age from engaging in the work of content creation. This funding would be used to
cover any additional responsibilities or staff needed by the Office of the Attorney General to
enforce the new regulations outlined in the bill.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from the general fund for the fiscal impact
of Senate Bill 1222, the Safeguarding American Veteran Empowerment Act. This legislation
would regulate the practices of persons seeking to receive compensation for preparing,
presenting, prosecuting, advising, consulting, or assisting any individual regarding any veterans'
benefits matter. The bill provides that a violation of its provisions constitutes a prohibited
practice under the Virginia Consumer Protection Act.

agencyName: Executive Offices FY24-25 FY25-26

of legislation, which establishes the Online Mar
descriptionFull:

of legislation, which establishes the Online Marketplace Consumer Protection Act and makes it
a prohibited practice under the Virginia Consumer Protection Act for any supplier in connection
with a consumer transaction to sell, offer for sale, or facilitate the sale, including on an online
website or through the supplier's warehouse or distribution center, of stolen goods.

agencyName: Executive Offices FY24-25 FY25-26

descriptionFull:

fiscal impact of Senate Bill 769, which requires the privacy notice that a controller must provide
to consumers to include a method by which a consumer may opt out of the automatic placement
of a data file, commonly referred to as a "cookie," on the consumer's computer or web browser
Item Order 25
Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
and a disclosure of the purposes for which the data files are used. The bill prohibits controllers
from using cookies, except those that are strictly necessary, without the prior express consent of
the consumer and prohibits controllers from preventing access to their services if such consent
is not granted.

agencyName: Administration FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment includes language that expands the number of inmates for whom localities
receive the state-responsible jail per diem payment
descriptionFull:
This amendment includes language that expands the number of inmates for whom localities
receive the state-responsible jail per diem payment rate of $15 and provides $250,000 GF the
second year as a placeholder estimate for the fiscal impact of the language. The language
establishes that, for any convicted felon whose sentence includes time in a state correctional
facility or under state community supervision and who has been placed in jail due to a violation
of the terms of their community supervision, the Department of Corrections shall either relocate
the inmate to a state correctional facility within 10 days or the locality shall begin receiving $15
per day, as opposed to the $5 per day rate for local-responsible inmates.

court clerks' offices. The goal of the amendment is to address recruitment and retention
challenges.

This amendment provides $7.5 million GF the first year for the Virginia Port Authority to

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $7.5 million GF the first year for the Virginia Port Authority to
conduct a dredging project to facilitate marine transport access to the Mid-Atlantic Regional
Spaceport on Wallops Island. Operational marine infrastructure is needed to transport
components for large rockets to the site. Potential interim solutions have been identified,
including dredging around an existing dock at Wallops Island. This investment will serve all
commercial partners at the spaceport until longer term solutions are implemented, ensuring that
the Virginia spaceport stays competitive.

fiscal impact of legislation to be introduced related to Juvenile Detention Center Consolidation.
The legislation designates six local juvenile detention centers for closure, which may result in
the elimination of up to 69.0 education positions under the State Operated Program at the
Department of Education. A portion of savings may be reallocated to other purposes, including
covering local costs that may change because of the closures such as travel expenses and any
increased costs at juvenile detention centers housing additional youth. The goal of the
legislation is to realize savings for both state and local government.

Funds are expected to provide pro bono legal services to support underrepresented members of

to become effective legal advocates.

education programs in conjunction with The College of William and Mary and the Presidential
Precinct.

small businesses aware of transition options and ensure that technical assistance is available.

descriptionFull:

George Mason University to conduct a study on potential revenue from placing a fee on all
parking spaces on privately owned/commercial property, including surface lots and parking
structures within the Northern Virginia Transportation Commission and Potomac and
Rappahannock Transportation Commission Districts and potential revenue from the districts
surrounding Metro stations and to help determine methods for establishing a permanent revenue
source for Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority by creating a tax overlay district
around every Metro station pursuant to SJ28 of the 2024 General Assembly Session.

agencyName: Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $450,000 GF in each year of the biennium to increase dedicated
funding for Tick Borne Illness/Lyme Disease research
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $450,000 GF in each year of the biennium to increase dedicated
funding for Tick Borne Illness/Lyme Disease research and medical test development. It will
scale current test technology to provide rapid, 95% accurate, at-home diagnostics, providing
timely diagnosis and treatment of Lyme Disease across the Virginia. This funding is intended to
be recurring and would provide one full time nurse and two full time lab technicians to process,
analyze and perform tests, lab supplies, and support additional research to continue to refine
methods, clinical trials and long term sustainability of this incredible step to combating these
forms of tick borne disease.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4.0 million the second year to establish the Earn to Learn
Behavioral Health Education Acceleration program. The pr
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.0 million the second year to establish the Earn to Learn
Behavioral Health Education Acceleration program. The program provides opportunities for
students seeking a behavioral health professional career to complete their clinical education
while gaining employment experience. The amendment requires the Department of Health to
establish criteria for making grants from the program, including application guidelines and
metrics for evaluation. Grants will be awarded to form collaborative clinical training
arrangements between high schools, colleges and universities, hospitals, and health providers,
increase the number of students receiving necessary clinical training to achieve certification and
create and ensure employment opportunities for students seeking careers as a behavioral health
clinician. To be eligible for grants, applicants must provide employment opportunities to
students at each student's current certification level with compensation consistent with other
employees at identical certification levels. They must demonstrate that the grant application will
increase, on a net basis, the number of graduates achieving sufficient clinical hours to achieve
behavioral health certifications, compared to averages over the past five years.

The Earn to Learn program offers competitive grants to both public and nonprofit private
colleges and universities that partner with health systems to offer nursing students the
opportunity to earn a competitive wage while also earning credit for clinical hours toward
degree requirements. The goal of the program is to address the health care workforce shortage
by expanding the number of trained nurses in Virginia.

descriptionFull:

Healthcare Workforce Development Authority for a dedicated Behavioral Health Workforce
Administrator position to review current workforce initiatives in behavioral health and
recommend efficient, scalable solutions to address workforce challenges statewide. The position
would evaluate existing programs, propose enhancements to health workforce incentive
programs, and support recruitment and retention efforts in the behavioral health sector.
Establishing an Administrator position dedicated to issues impacting the behavioral health
workforce would allow for greater focus to be placed on solving issues that impact this segment
of the healthcare workforce. The Administrator could also coordinate various workforce

descriptionFull:

University dental students' housing, and the E.C. Glass High School externship program.

descriptionFull:

Program to allow the Department of Health's Office of Drinking Water to test and treat
contaminated drinking water through grants for the use of eligible treatment or filtration
systems in private residential wells. The bill also directs the State Board of Health to adopt
regulations to utilize point-of-use or point-of-entry drinking water treatment or filtration
systems to remove or significantly reduce concentrations of contaminants of concern that meet
or exceed any maximum contaminant level or health advisory for the same contaminant adopted

descriptionFull:

wells of a number of homes in Eastern Henrico. In addition to their immediate efforts to provide
filtration, testing, and alternative clean water options for these homes, Henrico County

ultimately connect these and many other communities within this portion of the county to
municipal water.

descriptionFull:

cigars or 30 cents per cigar, whichever is less, consistent with Senate Bill 1162 as proposed.

descriptionFull:

and therefore has the highest cost of services compared to other Virginia rehabilitation
hospitals. The Department of Medical Assistance Services' rates pool the costs of all
Item Order 187
Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
rehabilitation hospitals, so Sheltering Arms Rehabilitation Centerโs relative reimbursement is
lower. For FY 2025, Sheltering Arms Rehabilitation Center will be reimbursed at less than 69.0
percent of cost for inpatient services while other providers are reimbursed at closer to 80.0
percent. This supplemental payment helps make up that gap.

descriptionFull:
This amendment reflects savings of $14.0 million general fund and $14.0 million nongeneral
funds related to the fiscal impact of Senate Bill 875. The pharmacy benefit represents a
significant and expanding segment of Medicaid expenses. Many states are actively
implementing and finding savings with proven strategies to manage the escalating costs. The
savings outlined in this budget amendment are derived from the Department of Medical
Assistance Services' November 2019 report, which assesses the fiscal impacts of implementing
a single, transparent Pharmacy Benefits Manager to administer the pharmacy benefit.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources
descriptionShort:
This amendment eliminates the automatic Medicaid Expansion termination language in the
Appropriation Act. Should the federal match rate chan
descriptionFull:
This amendment eliminates the automatic Medicaid Expansion termination language in the
Appropriation Act. Should the federal match rate change, a legislative committee must be
established to consider ways to adjust to the federal action while preserving access to health
coverage for as many currently eligible individuals as possible. Medicaid Expansion provides
health coverage to over 636,000 Virginians. Current budget language mandates the automatic
termination of this health coverage without legislative review. The Joint Subcommittee would
report its findings and recommendations within 45 days of the federal action.

descriptionFull:

nonopioid drug approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment or
management of pain shall be disadvantaged or discouraged for coverage relative to any opioid.

pain.

funds the second year for the fiscal impact of Senat
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $968,704 from the general fund and $2.3 million from nongeneral
funds the second year for the fiscal impact of Senate Bill 831, which directs the Department of
Medical Assistance Services to seek federal authority to implement presumptive eligibility for
pregnant individuals, in addition to the existing hospital presumptive eligibility program and, if
the department receives such authority, allows the department to authorize qualified entities to
make determinations of presumptive eligibility for pregnant individuals. This amendment
provides funding for the Department of Medical Assistance Services to seek federal authority
through any necessary State Plan amendments to implement presumptive eligibility for pregnant
women in accordance with 42 C.F.R. ยง 435.1103. Funding shall cover necessary systems
updates, hiring personnel as needed, and other costs. Expenses are expected to be higher in year
one due to start-up costs, and expenses in both years consider FFP of 50.0 percent. The
department shall determine the methods used by qualified entities to verify income and shall
implement quality control measures to reduce the risk of fraud or error. The department already
has quality control measures in place for Hospital Presumptive Eligibility and may be able to
use similar methods for this policy, which should offset costs. Additionally, should a completed

Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
application not be submitted by the last day of the month in which screening occurs, coverage
will cease meaning that an individual cannot be covered for longer than 60 days without filing a
completed application.

recipientRawText: for Hospital Presumptive Eligibility and may be able to use similar methods for this policy, which should offset costs

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $18.0 million the second year from the general fund for
implementation of Marcus Alert programs. This is a state man
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $18.0 million the second year from the general fund for
implementation of Marcus Alert programs. This is a state mandated co-response model that also
integrates 911 dispatch with the 988-crisis line. Both of these elements combine to provide
opportunities to divert individuals in crisis from the criminal justice system as well as
potentially from inpatient hospitalization. Six sites that were supposed to implement in 2024
had completed their planning but the funding to support implementation was not included in the
Item Order 227
Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
budget. This funding supports the six sites that have completed their planning as well as an
additional six sites, which will allow Virginia to keep pace to have all of the programs in place
by 2028, which is when the Code of Virginia dictates every locality in Virginia, except for
smaller localities, to have implemented a Marcus Alert program. The funding would bring all
programs to full funding including those that have already been implemented.

descriptionFull:

landscape assessment and strategic response plan to human trafficking as well as to establish a
statewide referral mechanism to connect survivors to appropriate services and collect data on
trafficking trends. This amendment includes $100,000 for the assessment and strategic response
plan and $250,000 to contract with an external agency, such as Safewatch, to create the referral

detailing program on the assessment and response plan, outcomes from the referral mechanism,
and recommendation for future funding and program expansion.

This amendment provides $1.4 million GF the first year to Albemarle County for the design
and construction of an accessible walking trail th
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.4 million GF the first year to Albemarle County for the design
and construction of an accessible walking trail that connects Biscuit Run Park to the future
Monacan Indian Nation Tribute Park in the Southwood Mobile Home Park redevelopment
project. This would be the first investment by the Commonwealth for the park's development,
and due to the size of the park, it is a regional asset that will welcome visitors from beyond
Albemarle County.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $5.0 million GF the first year and $5.0 million GF the second year to
the Virginia Outdoors Foundation for the Get Outdoors Fund. The fund supports studies,
planning, concept development, capacity building, programming, and infrastructure to enable
safe use of or access to public open space, as well as for land acquisition through grants to state,
local, regional, or tribal government entities, educational institutions, or non-profit
organizations. Priority is given to shovel-ready projects with tangible, measurable results.

Quality expand ground water research in the Easte
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.3 million GF the first year for the Department of Environmental
Quality expand ground water research in the Eastern Groundwater Management Areas. The
funding includes support for multi-well research stations and resources to conduct a study to
determine technically feasible locations to recommend water treatment upgrades modeled on
the Hampton Roads Sanitation District SWIFT project and the cost of such upgrades. The
analysis would be provided to the Chairs of the State Water Commission, House Committee on
Agriculture, Chesapeake, and Natural Resources, and Senate Committee on Agriculture,
Conservation, and Natural Resources by July 1, 2026.

agencyName: Public Safety and Homeland Security FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $92,000 GF the second year for the potential fiscal impact to the
Department of Corrections of Senate Bill 1134, whi
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $92,000 GF the second year for the potential fiscal impact to the
Department of Corrections of Senate Bill 1134, which requires any person who possesses a
firearm in a residence where such person knows that a minor or a person who is prohibited by
law from possessing a firearm is present to store such firearm and ammunition in a locked
container, compartment, or cabinet that is inaccessible to the minor or prohibited person. In the
fiscal impact for a similar bill, Senate Bill 368 in the 2024 General Assembly Session, the
Department of Corrections indicated that the agency may purchase biometric storage devices for
its officers that carry a firearm to meet the bill's intent.

intimate partner or an offense substantially similar under the laws of any other state or of the
United States is guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor.

Corrections Special Reserve Fund, pursuant to ยง 30-19.1:4, Code of Virginia, to address the
projected corrections bedspace fiscal impact of Senate Bill 848, which raises the minimum age
to 21 for purchasing assault firearms and specifies that buyers must consent in writing for
dealers to obtain criminal history records before completing the sale. Dealers must verify the
buyer is at least 21. The proposal broadens the definition of an assault firearm, changing it from
one with a magazine holding over 20 rounds to one with a fixed magazine capacity exceeding
10 rounds.

agencyName: Public Safety and Homeland Security FY24-25 FY25-26

This amendment provides $500,000 GF the second year for the potential fiscal impact to the

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 GF the second year for the potential fiscal impact to the
Virginia State Police of Senate Bill 1134, which requires any person who possesses a firearm in
a residence where such person knows that a minor or a person who is prohibited by law from
possessing a firearm is present to store such firearm and ammunition in a locked container,
compartment, or cabinet that is inaccessible to the minor or prohibited person. In the fiscal
impact for a similar bill, Senate Bill 368 in the 2024 General Assembly Session, the Virginia
State Police indicated that the agency would purchase biometric storage devices for its sworn
officers to meet the bill's intent.

descriptionFull:

crossing violation and stop sign violation monitoring systems in school crossing zones, highway
work zones, and high-risk intersection segments for purposes of recording pedestrian crossing
and stop sign violations, as those terms are defined in the bill. The bill imposes the same
requirements on pedestrian crossing and stop sign violation monitoring systems as currently
exist for photo speed monitoring devices and requires local law-enforcement agencies
implementing or expanding the use of such systems to, prior to the implementation or expansion
of such systems, conduct a public awareness program for such implementation or expansion.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF the second year for the potential fiscal impact of Senate
Bill 1158 which makes various changes to provisions governing eminent domain, primarily
relating to procedures in condemnation proceedings and the transfer of a defeasible title by
certificate. The bill sets forth reasonable costs of discovery in condemnation proceedings and
Item Order 347
Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
provides that when a condemnor initiates discovery in a condemnation proceeding, such
condemnor shall pay all reasonable costs of such discovery. The bill also specifies that, in a
condemnation proceeding initiated by an authorized condemnor or the Commissioner of
Highways, a certificate transferring a defeasible title shall include certain information
describing the property and any rights to the property being taken or damaged. Finally, the bill
repeals the requirement that the court refer a matter initiating a condemnation proceeding to a
dispute resolution orientation.

agencyName: Central Appropriations FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from the general fund for the potential
fiscal impact of Senate Bill 860, which increases fr
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from the general fund for the potential
fiscal impact of Senate Bill 860, which increases from 52 weeks to 500 weeks the maximum
duration after the date of diagnosis that workers' compensation benefits are payable for post-
traumatic stress disorder, anxiety disorder, or depressive disorder incurred by law-enforcement
officers and firefighters acting in the line of duty. The bill also removes the prohibition on
medical treatment, temporary total incapacity benefits, or temporary partial incapacity benefits
from being awarded beyond four years from the date of the qualifying event that was the
primary cause of the post-traumatic stress disorder, anxiety disorder, or depressive disorder.

agencyName: Central Appropriations FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment transfers $10.0 million GF the second year to the Workers' Compensation
Commission to be deposited to the Mass Violence Care
descriptionFull:
This amendment transfers $10.0 million GF the second year to the Workers' Compensation
Commission to be deposited to the Mass Violence Care Fund proposed to be established by
House Bill 1711, introduced in the 2025 Session, pursuant to a companion amendment in Item
489. The $10.0 million appropriation was first provided in Chapter 1, 2023 Acts of Assembly,
Special Session I, for victims of mass violence and was unallotted pending a workgroup report
from the Department of Criminal Justice Services and adoption by the General Assembly of a
structure for administering the funds.
primaryRecipientName: the Workers' Compensation Commission to be deposited to the Mass Violence Care Fund proposed to be established by House Bill 1711

agencyName: Central Appropriations FY24-25 FY25-26
Independent Agencies
descriptionShort:
This amendment directs the State Corporation Commission, in collaboration with the Secretary
of Health and Human Resources, to convene a wor
descriptionFull:
This amendment directs the State Corporation Commission, in collaboration with the Secretary
of Health and Human Resources, to convene a workgroup to evaluate Bureau of Insurance
market conduct examinations of carriers licensed by the Bureau, with a report on findings and
recommendations to the Chairs of the Senate Committees on Commerce and Labor and
Education and Health, and the House Committees on Labor and Commerce and Health and
Human Services no later than November 1, 2025.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for any potential fiscal
impact of Seante Bill 1116, expands the definitions
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for any potential fiscal
impact of Seante Bill 1116, expands the definitions of "independent qualified trustee" and
"qualified trustee" to authorize additional entities to serve as an independent qualified trustee or
a qualified trustee of a qualified self-settled spendthrift trust.

descriptionFull:
This amendment directs the State Corporation Commission to commence a proceeding to

594.3 and 56-594.4 of the Code of Virginia, immediately upon the adoption of regulations
pursuant to subsection F of ยงยง 56-594.3 and 56-594.4 of the Code of Virginia, or July 1, 2025,
if no such proceeding has already commenced before then.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:

of Seante Bill 1243, which prohibits the costs
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the first year from nongeneral funds for the potential impact
of Seante Bill 1243, which prohibits the costs associated with the construction or extension of
any electric distribution infrastructure that primarily serves the load of a data center from being
recovered from any other customer.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $500,000 each year from nongeneral funds and 2.0 positions related
to the fiscal impact of implementation of energy
descriptionFull:

to the fiscal impact of implementation of energy innovation legislation to be considered in the
2025 Session.

agencyName: Member Amendments to SB 800, as Introduced
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from the general fund to account for the
fiscal impact of Senate Bill 1049 on the Virginia S
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from the general fund to account for the
fiscal impact of Senate Bill 1049 on the Virginia State Corporation Commission to review the
determination of overhead transmission lines. The bill prohibits the construction of a new
transmission line overhead unless the State Corporation Commission first determines that the
construction of such transmission line in whole or in part underground is not in the public
interest.
primaryRecipientName: the fiscal impact of Senate Bill 1049 on the Virginia State Corporation Commission to review the determination of overhead transmission lines
recipientRawText: for the fiscal impact of Senate Bill 1049 on the Virginia State Corporation Commission to review the determination of overhead transmission lines

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from general fund to the Bureau of
Insurance to cover the cost of five additional comprehens
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from general fund to the Bureau of
Insurance to cover the cost of five additional comprehensive analyses of new benefits
recommended by the Health Insurance Reform Commission as part of the application to the
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services in May 2026. The current contract with its actuary
covers up to five comprehensive analyses. Any appropriation that is unspent will revert to the
state treasury.

descriptionFull:

fund and is to be determined.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $40,000 the second year from the general fund for the fiscal impact
of Senate Bill 1142, which provides employees of
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $40,000 the second year from the general fund for the fiscal impact
of Senate Bill 1142, which provides employees of contributing nonprofit private institutions of
higher education with the benefits granted to employees of participating employers under the
Line of Duty Act. The bill clarifies that the Line of Duty Act shall not apply to any private
institution of higher education that is not a contributing nonprofit private institution of higher
education. The bill requires each contributing nonprofit private institution of higher education to
pay its pro rata share of the initial costs to implement the bill, as determined by the Virginia
Retirement System.

agencyName: Independent Agencies
descriptionShort:
This amendment increases the Hazardous Duty Supplement, which is provided to employees
who retire with at least 20 years of hazardous duty s
descriptionFull:
This amendment increases the Hazardous Duty Supplement, which is provided to employees
who retire with at least 20 years of hazardous duty service credit. This amendment provides a
supplement increase from the current amount of $1,407 per month to $1,800 per month in the
first year, and then from $1,800 to $2,200 per month in the second year. This increase would
cover the cost of family health care plans provided by the state.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $75,000 from nongeneral fund the second year for the fiscal impact
to Virginia Retirement System related to Senate B
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $75,000 from nongeneral fund the second year for the fiscal impact
to Virginia Retirement System related to Senate Bill 1292, which allows a retired sworn law-
enforcement officer who returns to employment in a regional criminal justice academy to
continue receiving his service retirement allowance.

agencyName: Independent Agencies FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from nongeneral funds the potential fiscal
impact for legislation that changes the age throu
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 the second year from nongeneral funds the potential fiscal
impact for legislation that changes the age through which a retired law-enforcement officer
covered under the Virginia Law Officers' Retirement System is entitled to receive an additional
retirement allowance from the law-enforcement officer's sixty-fifth birthday to full retirement
age as defined by the Social Security Act. This change aligns the additional allowance with that
currently provided under the State Police Officers' Retirement System.

agencyName: Independent Agencies
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides, that for the purpose of the property tax exemption for spouses of
law enforcement officers that were killed in the
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides, that for the purpose of the property tax exemption for spouses of
law enforcement officers that were killed in the line of duty, that such officer who was a
member of the U.S. Capitol Police or The Metropolitan Police Department of the District of
Columbia who was actively involved in the police response to the Insurrection that occurred on
January 6, 2021, qualifies the spouse for the exemption. Current law requires the officer to be
employed by the Commonweath or its political subdivisions.

agencyName: Independent Agencies
descriptionShort:
This amendment directs the Virginia Retirement System to coordinate with the Department of
Education, the Department of Human Resource Mange
descriptionFull:
This amendment directs the Virginia Retirement System to coordinate with the Department of
Education, the Department of Human Resource Mangement, the Virginia Association of
Counties, Virginia Municipal League, the Virginia School Boards Association, and stakeholders
for state and local government employees to determine whether the elimination of the
traditional Virginia Retirement System defined benefit pension has affected the Commonwealth
and localities' ability to retain state and local government employees, including but not limited,
to teachers.
